message.content:
Prunus mexicana, commonly known as Mexican plum or Texas plum, is a deciduous flowering tree native to Mexico and the southwest United States. 
It typically grows from 15 to 35 feet in height and 12 to 20 feet in width with a rounded, spreading crown. 
The leaves are simple, alternate, ovate to elliptic in shape, and dark green in color with a slightly serrated margin. 
In the spring, clusters of fragrant white to pink flowers bloom before leaves emerge. 
The fruit of Prunus mexicana is a small, round and edible plum that is dark purple to black when ripe. 
It prefers full sun to partial shade and can be found in a variety of habitats such as woodlands, hillsides, and along streams. 
Mexican plum is commonly used in landscaping and as a wildlife food source for birds and mammals.
